original: It was a fascinating talk and the speaker really hit the nail on the head with a couple of things. Take parental influence, for instance. original: As for news stories that make us think the world is an increasingly violent place, there is cause for some optimism too. However, terrorism has shot up in the last few years and, since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. Even for civilians, though, the statistics are not all bad. simplified:
Some news stories make us think the world is becoming more violent, but there is also reason to be hopeful. Between the end of World War II and 1990, there were 30 wars that killed over 100,000 people. Today, there are still civil wars, but most countries live together more peacefully than before. However, terrorism has increased in recent years, and since World War II, wars have killed more civilians than soldiers.

For civilians, the news is not all bad. While violent crime is nine times more likely to cause death than political conflict, the global murder rate has dropped a little. In 2000, there were 8 murders per 100,000 people, but by 2015, it had fallen to about 5.3.

original: In an attempt to inject some positivity into their feedback, many managers rely on sandwiching negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when feedback becomes such a routine, employees can start to perceive positive feedback as simply a form of sugarcoating the negatives, thus diminishing its value. Instead, positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative, but should be delivered so as to reinforce and encourage good performance.
simplified: Many managers try to give positive feedback by putting negative comments between two positive ones. But if this happens too often, employees may think the positive feedback is just hiding the bad news. This makes the positive feedback less meaningful. Positive feedback should not just be used to soften bad news. Instead, it should be given to support and encourage good work.

original: I'm a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. simplified: I am part of a group called the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don’t think of scary movie robots crushing skulls. This seems very wrong and dangerous for people. We must be very careful about what we let machines do.

original: A fast-paced, foot-tapping rock album, Born in the USA's lyrics nevertheless carry emotional weight. Behind the catchy rock melodies that drive these powerhouse classics are stories of the dark side of the American dream. Many tracks deal with the struggles of hard-working ordinary people and the bitterness and anger they feel as life doesn't bring them riches or glory. The song Glory Days, for example, is about people in a small town looking back at when they were young and had the world at their feet while Downbound Train tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job. It's not hard to imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew and the life he might have had if he hadn't become a star. The album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.
simplified: *Born in the USA* is a lively rock album with catchy songs, but the lyrics are deep and meaningful. The music is fun, but the words tell sad stories about the American dream. Many songs are about ordinary people who work hard but never get rich or famous. For example, *Glory Days* is about people remembering their youth when life was better. *Downbound Train* tells the story of a young man whose life falls apart after losing his job. The singer might be writing about real people he knew or imagining his own life if he hadn’t become famous. The album shows how talented the artist is.
name: mistral-medium-3_short

original: Lewis would like to see the number of marine protected areas in the world increase from 3 per cent to 10 per cent in an attempt to reverse the damage caused by human activity such as overfishing, polluting and littering. original: In the 1950s, Central American commercial banana growers were facing the death of their most lucrative product, the Gros Michel banana, known as Big Mike. With its easily transported, thick-skinned and sweet-tasting fruit, the Gros Michel banana plant dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit, the main grower and exporter in South America at the time, mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible: it cloned shoots from the stems of plants instead of growing plants from seeds, and cultivated them in densely packed fields.
simplified:
In the 1950s, banana farmers in Central America had a big problem. Their most popular banana, called the Gros Michel or "Big Mike," was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to the Cavendish banana, which replaced the Gros Michel.

The Gros Michel was very popular because it was easy to transport, had thick skin, and tasted sweet. It grew on many farms in Central America. The main company, United Fruit, grew these bananas in a simple way. Instead of using seeds, they took shoots from the plants and grew them close together in large fields.

original: Spider venom is present in most species and serves the purpose of stunning or killing their prey rather than attacking humans. In fact, only 25 of the known spider species produce venom which can actually harm humans, and although spider bites can be painful, they are rarely deadly. Australia's notorious Sydney funnel-web spider has not produced any fatalities since anti-venom was developed in 1981. However, take care not to rub hairy spiders like tarantulas up the wrong way. When they feel in danger, they defend themselves by ejecting a cloud of urticating hairs. These irritating hairs then embed themselves in the skin or eyes of the attacker.
simplified: Most spiders have venom to catch their food, not to hurt people. Only 25 types of spiders can harm humans, and their bites are usually painful but not deadly. For example, Australia’s Sydney funnel-web spider has not caused any deaths since 1981 because of anti-venom. But be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. If they feel threatened, they can shoot out tiny hairs that irritate the skin or eyes.

original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified:
To understand where our ability for complex language comes from, we must look at how our brains differ from other animals. It’s not just about brain size; it’s also about what else our brains can do and when and why these abilities developed. However, there are very few physical clues. Objects left by our ancestors don’t tell us what kind of speech they could produce.

One thing we can see in early human remains is the development of the mouth, throat, and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess if early humans used simpler sounds to communicate.
name: mistral-medium-3_short

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. Coupled with this is the lack of positive female role models youngsters see doing science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man. Furthermore, there is an unfortunate perception that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes portrayed by the media, but they may mean that girls do not identify with scientists, and see science as an unappealing career path. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.
simplified: Society, not nature, tells girls that arts and humanities are for them, while maths and physics are for boys. There are also few female role models in science jobs. In cartoons and stories, scientists, inventors, and astronauts are usually men. Many people also think scientists are geeky, bad at socializing, or work alone. These ideas are wrong, but they make girls feel science is not for them. If girls saw more successful women in science, they would feel more confident and welcome in these subjects.
